intro-screen.paragraph: Every second, billions of packets are on their way to their final destination on the internet. These pieces of data travel from router to router, often crossing the boundaries of multiple autonomous systems. They blindly trust the Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) to choose the best route. But BGP works based on information it receives from other networks, and that information is not always correctâ€¦

pakketjes.explanation: A packet is a piece of data, for example: an email, a video stream, or a request to visit a website.

router.explanation: A router forwards packets to the next stop based on instructions from protocols like BGP.

autonome-systemen.explanation: An autonomous system is a collection of networks under the management of one organization, such as an internet provider or a large company.

bgp.explanation: BGP is the protocol used to determine the best route to a destination outside the current autonomous system

about-packet-panic.title: About Packet Panic
about-packet-panic.paragraph1: Packet Panic is an educational game developed by Studio Tast for the SIDN call 'Internet inBeeld' to explain the underlying infrastructure of the internet in an understandable way.
about-packet-panic.paragraph2: Packet Panic focuses on the dangers of BGP hijacking: the manipulation and interception of internet traffic by cybercriminals. BGP is an essential but vulnerable part of the internet. The internet was developed by a group of researchers who collaborated based on trust. BGP still relies on that same mutual trust. There are ways to make BGP less vulnerable, but they are only effective if they are widely implemented.
about-packet-panic.paragraph3: The goal of Packet Panic is to raise awareness among more people about the vulnerabilities of the Border Gateway Protocol (BGP). Through the game, players gain insight into how BGP hijacking works, what the dangers are, and what solutions are available.

news-article.title: BGP: the Achilles heel of the internet
news-article.content: BGP often works fine. But what the creators didn't foresee is that the internet would become a place where not everyone is always honest. Due to the lack of authentication, you can't verify if a route announced via BGP is correct.

news-article.title: Pakistan BGP error takes down YouTube
news-article.content: In March 2008, YouTube was down for millions of users for hours. The Pakistani government tried to block YouTube in their country. But due to an error in the BGP configuration, they redirected traffic from other countries to Pakistani networks.

news-article.title: $235,000 in cryptocurrency stolen through BGP hijack
news-article.content: In September 2022, an error at Amazon led to the theft of $235,000 in cryptocurrency. Traffic was redirected to a fake website that looked like a legitimate cryptocurrency service, where hackers stole visitors' crypto.

news-article.title: RPKI: a safer BGP within reach
news-article.content: RPKI uses digital signatures to verify BGP routes. Routers check if the signatures are correct; if not, the route is rejected, which prevents attacks and mistakes.

end-screen.title: Congratulations, you've completed Packet Panic!
end-screen.paragraph1: Hopefully you felt like you were constantly playing catch-up. What if you get notifications that a website is unavailable? How can you be sure that a route announced by BGP is trustworthy?
end-screen.paragraph2: Packet Panic is intentionally a frustrating game. Because BGP hijacks are a frustrating reality. RPKI is a good solution, but only works really well with 100% adoption. We're not there yet. The counter is still stuck at 50%
end-screen.paragraph3: Now you know that too. So help get RPKI adoption to 100%.
end-screen.paragraph4: Thank you for playing Packet Panic.
